caption.body: Choreographer Danielle Roweâ€™s first repertory length work for San Francisco Ballet faced a complex path due to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. ğ˜ğ˜°ğ˜°ğ˜¥ğ˜¦ğ˜¯ ğ˜‹ğ˜ªğ˜®ğ˜¦ğ˜´, a 1920s Art Deco ballet takes its name from an American saying of the era, â€œDonâ€™t take any wooden nickels,â€ a caution to be careful not to get swindled. For the narrative, Rowe explains, â€œI wanted to look at that space between what I call the real world and the magical world of the theater; particularly the dressing room space, where you put on makeup, change your hair, and transform into somebody else. It can consume you as a performerâ€”thereâ€™s an energy and shared experience in that space thatâ€™s like nothing else.â€ Roweâ€™s story revolves around a married couple, Robert and Betty Fine. As a chorus girl, Betty rises to stardom and Robert remains stuck in a dull, repetitive job.   Special thank you to San Francisco Ballet for making this exhibition possible. See â€œSan Francisco Ballet at 90â€ on display, pre-security, in the International Terminal and online at: https://bit.ly/SFBalletAt90  #SFBalletAt90 San Francisco Ballet
